Title: Ingham immortalises local sugar industry through art
Primary image caption: Local business owner Karen Venables and visual artist Kate Carr are the brains behind the public mosaic. Karen came up with the idea after visiting the town of Sheffield in Tasmania a few years ago. "It's only a very small town but the artwork within the community was really mind-blowing," she said. "There are murals along the walls of the little shops and cafes [and] the artwork that was in the information centres was done by artists all over Australia, there was leadlighting, there was marble, there was mosaic, there was graffiti art - it just captured my imagination of what we could have for Ingham."

Title: The secrets behind Toowoomba’s ‘deliberately restrained’ theatre
Primary image caption: Passers-by could easily miss the work of Paul Chrismas and Mark Tendys. Tucked behind the Empire Church Theatre, and right next door to the famous art deco Empire Theatre, is a simple concrete and glass structure. Mr Tendys says he wanted his building to give prominence to what was already on the site. "It was a conscious design decision. We never set out to try and mimic either of the two existing theatres," he said.

Title: Archaeologists unearth remnants of early life in Drayton
Primary image caption: Professor Bryce Barker from the University of Southern Queensland is leading the dig in the grounds behind the Royal Bulls Head Inn in Drayton. "The current building the National Trust owns was established in the mid 1850s," he said. "We're excavating at the back of the inn to see what features we can find. There were lots of ancillary building associated with the inn. None of them are here anymore, so we're looking to find their foundations and artefacts from them."

Title: Ride to work (every) day
Primary image caption: John Hughes rides 19 kilometres each way to work, including several impressive hills through Toowoomba. "I don't mind it," he said. "I grew up in Brisbane where there was a lot more traffic. You don't think about work, you concentrate on the ride and it's a good mental exercise as well as a physical one." Mr Hughes says bike commuters do need to be organised. "There are a few logistic challenges. I take my clothes and food into work on the weekend. But my car doesn't sit outside in the sun all day and I get to enjoy the fresh air five days a week."

Title: Indigenous youth mourn past but look to future
Primary image caption: About 50 young people walked more than 200km from the old Aboriginal settlement at Taroom to Woorabinda; a journey hundreds of Aboriginal people were forced to make by the Government in 1926. The youth aged between 15 and 30 were given a taste of what the walk would have been like for their ancestors with cold nights and long days. Many of those who walked in 1926 had insufficent or limited clothing, inadequate food rations and disease was rife.

Title: Aboriginal sites etched in time
Primary image caption: Scar tree in Nambour. “The scar trees that are on the Sunshine Coast could be 200 to 400-years-old. They cut this with stone axes and notice that the tree still grew. Title: Retiring church singers share their 'secret' rock star story
Primary image caption: Music has played a major part in the lives of (l-r) Ruth Greenwood, Joan Thurrowgood, and her husband Arthur Thurrowgood. The three performed as the Joytones during the 1960s, playing to audiences all over the world. "We realise some people have no idea of what we used to do," Joan said. The days of playing as a self described '60s guitar group' are long behind them, but they have, up until now, kept playing music in their local church. "I'm silver haired now," Joan explained. "And I often wonder what the young people think when we're up on the platform. Do they say to themselves, 'what are those old people doing up there'. They don't know our history."
Primary image rights information: Copyright: AAP | Source: ABC Southern Qld | Byline: Peter Gunders

Title: Too many dinosaur bones
Primary image caption: David Elliott with a dinosaur bone from a recent five-week dig around western Queensland. Mr Elliott says more than four tonnes of fossilised rock and dinosaur bone was brought back to Winton from the expedition. Five palettes are being stored at the Australian Age of Dinosaurs Museum, while four palettes are in his back shed. The Australian Age of Dinosaurs Museum opened in 2009, and is now in the process of expanding to tell the extended story of Australia’s evolution.

Title: Behind the screens at the Vision Splendid Outback Film Festival
Primary image caption: The Royal Open Air Theatre in Winton has been in Peter Evert’s family since 1938. He’s allowed the theatre to be used for the Vision Splendid Outback Film Festival and says he is delighted the historic building is being given another chance at life. Mr Evert says he believes the festival could one day compare to the Sundance Film Festival in the United States. “That’s evolved into a unique form of festival, and this could do that, concentrating on Australian movies rather than international ones and build up from there. I hope it is a success, I’ve got a feeling it’s going to work.”

Title: Ancient trails may be revived in southern Queensland
Primary image caption: "In my daily travel I'm always looking for sites," said Tim Knox, Aboriginal Programs Regional Coordinator with the Queensland Murray Darling Committee. "I often see scarred trees and evidence of Aboriginal occupation. We've discovered seven to eight rock wells scattered between Dirranbandi and the Bunya Mountains. They are situated on an ironstone outcrop. They'd light fires on them, remove the ash, and the water would seep through from the artesian basin. In Weengallon there's five or six wells. One is said to be 12 metres deep. In ancient times my people used to cover them, which would stop animals and debris falling in."
Primary image rights information: Copyright: AAP | Source: QMDC | Byline: supplied
Subjects: Community and Society:History, Community and Society:Indigenous (Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander):Indigenous Culture, Education:Subjects:History,

Title: Don't forget the D-Day sacrifice
Primary image caption: Reg Jones keeps an album of photos he took during the war years. He reminisces as he looks at a photo of himself when he first enlisted. "This young Reg didn't know what he was in for," he said. "I thought it'd all be over in six months." Mr Jones suffered a broken back from a bomb blast during the Battle of Britain, which meant he wasn't part of the fighting units that landed on French soil on June 6, 1944. He was later transferred to MI5 to serve in Germany after the war. "We were the spy catchers. I could tell you lots of stories, but I signed the official secrets act to make sure I didn't talk about it. But I've still got the memories."
Primary image rights information: Copyright: AAP | Source: from his archives | Byline: supplied

Title: Harriet’s cheeky expression steals show
Primary image caption: The Blackall Heartland Festival Photography Competition has three categories- black and white portraiture, landscape, and action split second. Paula Heelan took out the overall best picture award with her photograph ‘Harriet’. Photography judge Barry Alsop, who flew in from the Sunshine Coast for the event, says the picture is an iconic image of the outback. “Her face is saying a lot, and her eyes are saying a lot. She either might have just got into trouble for doing something, or she might be about to do something to get into trouble! It’s quite cheeky but it’s a beautiful portrait.”

Title: It’s a trap! Battles won in the war against the Indian Myna
Primary image caption: "They do a lot of damage to our native bird species because they out compete them for space, food and nesting hollows," Geoff Penton from the Queensland Murray Darling Committee said. "What we've observed, and what local people tell us, when they invade an area, our native bird numbers drop off pretty significantly." The bird is found throughout southern Queensland and "progressively spreading west," according to Mr Penton. "They're prevalent in Toowoomba and Dalby. They tend to follow areas of development, following the highways." Mr Penton says the Indian Myna is relatively easy to identify, "brown body, black head, with long yellow legs."
Primary image rights information: Copyright: AAP | Source: creative commons | Byline: Richard Taylor

Title: Ancient Indigenous site may become new Qld tourist spot
Primary image caption: A hand outlined in white ochre at ‘The Lost City’, a sacred site of the Bidjara people in the central interior of Queensland. Rock formations were used as canvases by the Bidjara people for thousands of years. To create this stencil and stencils like it, ochre was mixed with water in the mouth and spat around the hand. Such hand stencils can be found in sites all around Bidjara country in the Carnarvon Ranges.

Title: Momenta Monumenta
Primary image caption: "I've always been interested in how things don't last, and using a camera for moments of history," says Emilio Cresciani. "Tips are full of objects that have been used. I've inverted them as a negative. The negative consequence of our lifestyle is the rubbish. They kind of remind me as x-rays. We are constantly consuming and buying. Things don't last in this world. It could either be because we lose them, technology changes, or because they wear out. That fascinates me."

Title: Wine tails
Primary image caption: Muscat. Lucas Estate Wines. "He was an abandoned dog that turned up at the end of our road nearly six years ago," explains Louise Samuel. "I was a pretty sad person when I lost my husband, and people said 'get a dog', and Muscat turned up not long after. He works hard at the winery. He's a grape grader! He used to catch rats and mice, but the cats do that now. He always tells me when there's customers coming, and he's even on a label of mine. We made a pretty rough wine we named 'hair of the dog', but I think the dog was embarrassed, so we put a painting of him on a Liquor Muscat! I'm pretty sure he thinks the grape variety was named after him!"
Primary image rights information: Copyright: AAP | Source: ABC Southern Qld | Byline: Peter Gunders

Title: Remembering the Rats of Tobruk
Primary image caption: Rat of Tobruk Henry Tranter from Millaa Millaa in the Atherton Tablelands is now 96 years old and made the journey south to be part of the ceremony with his daughter Mary Jane Salleras. Mr Tranter was a signaller during the Siege of Tobruk. He said there was no way they could have known back then how important their part would be during the war. “The general said when the siege first started, here there’ll be no surrender and no retreat so we knew we were there to stay.”

Title: Would you cop it?
Primary image caption: Queensland Police are in the midst of a recruitment drive around the state. Inspector Mark Henderson from the Longreach Police says this South Australian police poster from 1838 shows how much has changed since those early recruitment days. “They really only looked for men. They looked for men who could ride horses, they looked for men who could fight, you had to be a certain height, a certain weight, and really not a lot else went into it. Now we are obviously in a community and we represent and police a community that’s multifaceted, multidimensional and multicultural.”

Title: Vivid memories of Spring Bluff march 72 years on
Primary image caption: At the time the soldiers had no idea where they were going. They boarded a train to Brisbane, and then travelled to New Guinea, where they would go on to win one of the most significant battles of WW2, the Battle of Milne Bay. Each year, the anniversary of the march is commemorated with a memorial service at the station. This year, there are only two surviving members of the 1000 strong battalion that made the trip; Bert Miles and Kevin Olsen.

Title: Newly discovered spiders named after jellybeans and former Greens leader
Primary image caption: Dr Barbara Baehr from the Queensland Museum discovered Leichhardteus badius, or reddish brown swift spider, in the Bunya Mountains. "The swift spider looks a bit like an ant," Dr Baehr says. "It's about the size of an ant, runs like an ant, and lives with the ants. But it lives on the ants. It's a ground spider. It's common in the rainforest." Dr Baehr says the 'brown' was chosen to honour former Greens senator Bob Brown, who rescued rainforest environments. "They're good creatures to work with. They are not dangerous to us, but we need them to keep a safe and healthy environment."
Primary image rights information: Copyright: AAP | Source: Supplied | Byline: Qld Museum

Title: Shandee Blackburn: memories of an angel
Primary image caption: For Shandee's mother, Vicki Blackburn, there are too many happy memories of her baby girl. “My first and probably happiest memory was when she was born. She nearly didn’t make it, I had an emergency ceasar. We rushed in and then I had a reaction to the epidural and then I woke up after surgery and I didn’t know if she’d made it or not. I said to my husband, 'where’s the baby?' and he said, 'she’s looking at you.' And they had her in my arms and she was just laying there looking at me. That was sweet. She had strawberry blonde hair, just that blonde hair with that tinge of pink in it so I thought, here’s trouble.”

Title: Previewing the new Bendigo Library
Primary image caption: The library was designed with sustainable principles in mind, and part of this is the 'Lantern'. A massive skylight in the roof admits light into the 'Lantern' structure, which then disperses and reflects the light through both levels of the library. Title: One year on from Jundah’s wild storm
Primary image caption: The undercover play area at Jundah State School leaning to the side after the storm on January 15, 2013. Barcoo Shire Council mayor Julie Groves says the structure was finally pulled down last weekend and will hopefully be replaced before the 2014 school year begins. “Parents were just really worried, in a strong wind you could actually see the building moving.” The structure was surrounded by a security fence to prevent people from walking underneath it.

Title: Morpeth's Mysterious Map
Primary image caption: Within the papers of the late Emeritus Professor A.P. Elkin lies an early plan of the township of Morpeth. It is clearly dated 22nd June 1849, but bears no markings of authorship. The plan measures approx. 36cm x 27.5cm, marked in pencil and ink, with a light watercolour wash. The construction materials of the extant buildings are identified as Red for brick, Yellow for stone, and Green for wood.

Title: A legend through the lens
Primary image caption: "This was taken on the road with Slim," Toowoomba-based John Elliott says. "He was doing concerts at night, and we would try and take pictures through the day. We were driving near Wangaratta and I saw this beautiful old shed. I honked, went in, looked around, and there was a farmer on his back under a truck. He was fixing the truck. I said 'hello!' He didn't get out from under the truck, and I said 'I'm a photographer, I've got Slim Dusty in the car, would you mind if I took a few pictures of him against your shed?' He said 'yeah mate, help yourself.' I'm sure he never realised I was telling the truth! I hope he got to see that picture one day."

Title: All smiles as Careflight helicopter returns to Mary Mackillop School
Primary image caption: It was a sea of smiles as the Careflight rescue helicopter touched down on the oval at Mary Mackillop School on Wednesday morning. It's a far cry from the events that led the chopper to visit seven months ago to airlift five-year-old Patrick O'Sullivan to hospital after a school fete accident. "When we hear the noise of choppers now, we think twice," says Donaugh Shirley, principal of Mary Mackillop School. "Everything's almost back to normal now. We call Patrick our own little miracle. He's back to school full time, and integrating with the children with no worries at all."

Title: Through a local lens
Primary image caption: "I was a bit embarrassed when they called the exhibition 'Icons on Icons'," says John Elliott. "It put a bit of pressure on me! One shot that came to mind, probably my most famous picture, is a really beautiful snapshot of Dame Edna and Slim Dusty. I took it in 1992 backstage at a concert in the Kimberly. It was really just two mates hanging out. I had a flash on my camera and went 'click'. I think I took three or four frames, and I knew when I clicked the camera it was a really important image. Years later, I read they were going to open a National Portrait gallery in Canberra. I didn't know where the picture was, but I called the director and said 'I've got a shot you need for your gallery'. It took me six months to find it. They bought it before the gallery opened, and used it on the invite for the opening. And when you drive into the National Portrait Gallery now, I snuck in to have a look recently, there's a 12 metre version of it as you drive into the carpark! So it's nice to have a really beautiful print of that photo at the Cobb and Co."
Primary image rights information: Copyright: Audience submitted | Source: used with permission | Byline: John Elliott
Subjects: Arts and Entertainment, Arts and Entertainment:Photography, Arts and Entertainment:Visual Art, Arts and Entertainment:Visual Art:Photography
Keywords: photography,

Title: Helping hands
Primary image caption: “There is so much need, all the time," Wayne Davis says. "Not anyone can do the work of a doctor. But anyone can carry a brick! So it really showed me that anyone can do it, should you wish to. Your reality becomes quite different once you’ve seen it with your own eyes, and use your own hands. We built a home for this woman and son. The boy has Down Syndrome. They lived in a scratched-up bamboo leaf style shack on the river. Places like that get typhoons and floods often. To build a home for them felt great. With most of us in the group being Christian, it was wonderful to put our faith into action.”

Title: Prized megafauna skull on display
Primary image caption: Local farmer, and amateur palaeontologist, Ian Sobbe, says he received a call from the Cobb and Co museum when the fossil was discovered. "Less than a week after we recovered it we had another major flood, and we would have lost it". He says this Diprotodon is "probably the largest, and best preserved, skull we've found on the Darling Downs. It’s significant in terms of the size, and from the quality of preservation that's allowed us to see features we’ve never seen in other skulls previously."

Title: What makes a good photo?
Primary image caption: John says the choice to make this photo black and white was the right way to go. "I think if you had colour then the blue in the sky and the green of the trees behind would have distracted from the image, so converting it to black and white was a really good move on the part of the photographer." he said. "I like the way that you've got leading lines. The trousers form leading lines, coming up to the shoes, leading your eye into the photograph, those are the things that I liked about this particular photo."

Title: Remnants of civilisation
Primary image caption: In the dry creek bed of the ephemeral Evelyn Creek lays this ute wreck. It has clearly been deserted for some time and the owner has long since moved on. We don’t know where it was first abandoned, or even why. All we know is that flash flooding swept it along the creek bed, scoured the paintwork and left it wedged at a quirky angle between the creek bank and a gum tree. A covering of scrub acts to partially conceal and protect what remains. It may have once been used for station work, but more recently marksmen have used it for target practice, pock-marking bullet holes all over it.
Primary image rights information: Copyright: ABC | Source: ABC Open | Byline: Catherine Moir
Subjects: Arts and Entertainment:Photography, Community and Society:History,
Keywords: abc open, snapped: old, tibooburra, kim piddington, abandoned photography exhibition, photography, goldrush, history, milparinka heritage precinct, tibooburra sight and sound festival

Title: The Shades of November
Primary image caption: By 6 September 1999, an estimated 1500 people had taken refuge in the church and compound to escape violence in the district. In the early afternoon, militia and paramilitary forces surrounded the church and began to attack those inside. Among the first casualties were three Catholic priests who were shot or stabbed to death when they tried to intervene. Grenades were thrown and automatic weapons fired through the doors and windows. The church was then set on fire and people trying to flee the burning building were shot or hacked down with machetes. It is believed that as many as 200 people were killed in the space of just a few hours.
Primary image rights information: Copyright: ABC | Source: Used with permission | Byline: Chris Whitelaw
Subjects: Arts and Entertainment:Photography, Community and Society:History, Human Interest, Unrest, Conflict and War

Title: Food drop bag: 1970
Primary image caption: Until roads were built into south-west Tasmania, many of the state’s more remote walking destinations required expeditions of several weeks to reach. Title: Sailor hat: 1920
Primary image caption: This cap from the HMAS Sydney was made for, and presented to, Nancy Bentley (1914–1999) in 1920. It stands as evidence to a curious moment in Australia’s naval history, when six-year-old Nancy became the first female to be enlisted in the Royal Australian Navy. And all because Nancy was bitten by a snake at Port Arthur.

Title: Crocoite: less than 2000 years
Primary image caption: Crocoite, a brilliant orange-to-red lead chromate (PbCrO4), was first described in 1832 by F.S. Beudant from material found in Siberia’s Beresov district. Crocoite is rare on a world scale, having only been found in small amounts at places such as Brazil, Romania, the Philippines, Germany and South Africa. However, in western Tasmania, nature has surpassed itself in its formation of spectacular growths of this beautiful mineral.
Primary image rights information: Copyright: ABC licensed | Source: Used with permission | Byline: Collection: Tasmanian Museum and Art Gallery
Subjects: Science and Technology:Geology,

Title: Huon Pine: Up to 3000 years old
Primary image caption: Huon pine timber has a high oil content and is extremely durable. Early settlers valued it, particularly in the boat-building industry. Title: Ballets Russes competition photo gallery
Primary image caption: My brother, David, and I are dressed in fancy dress for a function at school. It was my last year in Infants School before I went on to Primary School. My mother had made both our outfits. She wasn't a particularly good sewer but I think she has done a pretty good job. I was supposed to be Little Bo Peep, but I seem to have lost my sheep. My outfit was made completely out of crepe paper and Mum had gone to a great deal of trouble in making the hooped skirt and pantaloons. I recall I hated the outfit and didn't want to wear it and much preferred David's Superman costume. It brings back fond memories as my Mum died in 2009 and I miss her greatly. We used this photo in a collage that we put together for her 90th birthday.

Title: We have a winner
Primary image caption: Judges comments: FROZEN IN FLIGHT is an amazing photograph that has captured an insect in flight.The image captures the viewers’ imagination as one endeavours to interpret the content within the photograph.Due to the images soft focus, we can only assume that this insect is a butterfly.The photographer has use a slow shutter speed to capture the movement of the insect’s wings whilst having the ability to keep the body in sharp focus. The colours within the photograph compliment each other and the blurred background keeps your focus on the main subject being the butterfly. The subject is position nicely in the frame that assists in providing the concept of flight and movement. The overall technique used has allowed this image to be bought to life. Overall an amazing image that is pleasant to view.
Primary image rights information: Copyright: ABC | Source: Flickr | Byline: divweena
Subjects: Arts and Entertainment:Photography,
Station: ABC New England North West NSW
